awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Interplay between the Conformational and Functional Space of Membrane Proteins and the Physicochemical Properties of the Surrounding Bilay
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological membranes and their constituents are involved in virtually all processes vital to living organisms, including the immune response. This research investigates how several agents of the immune response combine their antimicrobial effects by interacting with each other on bacterial cell membranes. The specific agents of interest are host defense peptides and copper ions. Host defense peptides are powerful molecules that act on a broad range of pathogenic cells, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Copper ions, which are present in immune cells, can damage the cell membranes of bacteria by oxidizing their phospholipids. Interestingly, some host-defense peptides contain a copper-binding motif that enables them to bind copper and become metallopeptides. In this project, the PIs will develop new bio-physical and biochemical tools to investigate how host defense metallopeptides and copper ions may synergize their antimicrobial effects. This project has the potential to produce new principles that could be useful to design novel antimicrobial biomaterials. In addition, the project will include activities that engage college and pre-college students from diverse backgrounds in hands-on science and enhance their analytical skills. The PIs will leverage the interdisciplinary and collaborative nature of their research, and passion for scientific research to spike scientific interest in young students and prepare high school students for a successful transition to college.  

The major goal of this research is a rigorous investigation of the interplay between host defense mechanisms at biological membranes. The molecular systems of interest are membrane-interacting host defense metallopeptides and other agents of the immune response that have the potential to unify their antimicrobial effects at lipid membranes. While host defense peptides have been studied for their ability to disrupt the conformational arrangement in bacterial cell membranes, the possibility that host defense peptides and other immune agents such as copper and oxidized lipids synergize their antimicrobial effects has not been explored on a molecular level. The PIs will test this hypothesis using peptides from fish (piscidins) and ticks (ixosins). They will leverage their expertise in the characterization of membrane assemblies and harness a platform of cutting-edge biophysical techniques (solid-state NMR, neutron diffraction, surface-sensitive methods) and biological assays to obtain structure-dynamics-function information on these metallopeptides under native-like conditions. The project will focus on model membranes to accurately and precisely control membrane composition and directly relate their molecular contents to specific functional and conformational behaviors of host defense metallopeptides and their interactions with bilayers. The project will feature assays on live cells relevant to the biological context of the chosen host defense peptides to investigate the contribution of lipid oxidation to the antimicrobial potency of the peptides, identify synergistic effects among peptides, and relate biological potencies to physicochemical properties. This project will generate multiple broad impact outcomes. First, the new findings and methodologies created will contribute to advancing scientific knowledge in the fields of membrane biophysics, structural biology, immunology, and biochemistry. These fundamental principles could be useful to design novel antimicrobial agents and biomaterials. Second, the scientific environment will foster partnerships between academia and national labs. Third, the outreach activities will stimulate the interest of college and pre-college students from diverse backgrounds in hands-on science, and enhance their analytical skills.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project, we set out to investigate how one important class of naturally occurring peptides achieve their remarkable antimicrobial activity. Specifically, we studied their behavior when in contact with lipid membranes and how this interaction affects their antimicrobial activity.

On the scientific front, we published our work on the fish peptides piscidin 1 and piscidin 3. This work demonstrated that the cytotoxicity of the parent peptides is improved after they bind copper ions. This is very exciting as both copper ions and antimicrobial peptides are important molecules used by hosts to defend themselves from pathogens but have always been studied as to independent entities. Our work shows that both of them act in synergy to potentiate their activity. We combined permeabilization and lipid-oxidation capability assays, with neutron reflectometry, impedance spectroscopy, neutron diffraction, and UV spectroscopy to demonstrate that metalated piscidin 3 is effective at damaging bilayers, causing water crevices near double bonds which are susceptible to oxidation. On an additional publication, we used bacterial cytological profiling in combination with principal component analysis (BCP-PCA) to show that the peptide clavanin A, isolated from tunicates, attacks microbes in three different ways. This is an important addition to the scientific literature since it demonstrates the complexity of the mechanisms behind the antimicrobial activity of peptides. In the recent past, our idea was that this class of peptides defeat microbes in just one way; however, now we know that they use different tools to attain their incredible antimicrobial efficacy. 

The project also assisted with the development of human resources.  Students in my research group, both graduate and undergraduate, regularly presented their progress in our weekly group meetings and in national and international conferences. This has allowed them to hone their presentation skills. Three graduate students obtained their Ph.D. degrees and are now part of the scientific workforce (two of them in the United States). The students who authored papers actively participated in the preparation of their manuscripts and enhanced their writing skills. The students who participated in this project wrote eleven papers in scientific journals and one book chapter. My students and other students in the Department of Chemistry also benefitted from the visit from Prof. Ella Mihailescu (Univ. of Maryland and IBBR, PI in this Collaborative Research Project) who presented her research at UConn and also gave an additional seminar on neutron diffraction to students interested in the topic.   

Overall, the findings of this project provided fundamental insight into the relationship between the physicochemical properties of host defense peptides and their effect on the peptide-lipid membrane interactions and their contribution to the antimicrobial activity. Specifically, throughout the years of funding, we developed a quick and reliable methodology to study the mode of action of host defense peptides, a methodology that will be very useful for researchers working on this field. Also, our participation on the review entitled “Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing of Antimicrobial Peptides to Better Predict Efficacy”, written by authors from the United States and Europe, will lead to finding better ways to test antimicrobial peptides and enhance our chances to find suitable peptides for further clinical development. In addition, the reviews and viewpoint we have published are important contributions that seek to standardize the way antimicrobial assays are performed. This is particularly important not only to be able to translate the work done in labs into useful agents in the clinic but also for machine learning approaches that require a large number of results under similar conditions.
